patterns: How to avoid getting infected?
How can I protect myself?
Is there any suggestions for people during COVID?
What should be done to prevent COVID?
How can I protect my child from COVID-19 infection?
How do I prepare my children in case of COVID-19 outbreak in our community?
How can I help protect myself?
What steps should parents take to protect children?
How can my family and I prepare for COVID-19?
What steps can my family take to reduce our risk of getting COVID-19?
How can I keep my family healthy?
What can I do to protect myself and prevent the spread of disease?
How can I protect myself from the spread of disease?
how can I avoid infection of COVID-19?
response: The most effective ways to protect yourself and others against COVID-19 are to frequently clean your hands, but plz also wear musk when you out.
Maintain a distance of at least 1 meter from people who are coughing or sneezing.
Before touching the mask, clean hands with an alcohol-based hand rub or soap and water.
Use alcohol-based hand rub or, if visibly soiled, wash your hands with soap and water.
Disposable medical face masks are intended for a single use only. After use they should be removed using appropriate techniques.

The following measures are not effective against COVID-2019: Smoking, Wearing multiple masksTaking antibiotics. You should maintain a distance of at least 1 meter from people who are coughing or sneezing.
Masks are an important method to protect. If you or your family members have fever, cough and difficulty breathing seek medical care early to reduce the risk of developing a more severe infection.
Masks are an important part of containing 2019-nCoV spread between people, along with other PPE and hand hygiene.

patterns: Can humans become infected with the COVID-19 from an animal source?
Can I catch COVID-19 from my pet?
response: Possible animal sources of COVID-19 have not yet been confirmed.
It is still too early to say whether animals could be theintermediate host in the transmission of the COVID-19.

patterns: Where can I find advice on health risks around mass gatherings?
what can we do to reduce the risk of participants catching COVID-19, if we go ahead with a mass gathering?
response: Promote hand washing, respiratory hygiene and social distancing at the event.
You should consider whether the number of participants at the event could be reduced, making available participation by video or teleconference.
Possibly screening participants for COVID-19 symptoms at points of entry to the venue.
You need to consider the location and duration of the event as well as the number of participants.

All countries should seriously consider postponing or reducing mass gatherings that bring people together and have the potential to amplify disease and support the recommended best practice of physical distancing.

patterns: Whats the source of COVID-19?
Is the source of the coronavirus causing COVID-19 known?
Was ist die Quelle des Virus?
response: The virus that causes COVID-19 and the one that caused the outbreak of SARS are related to each other genetically.
Currently, the source of SARS-CoV-2, the coronavirus (CoV) causing COVID-19 is unknown.
All available evidence suggests that SARS-CoV-2 has a natural animal origin and is not a constructed virus.
SARS-CoV-2 virus most probably has its ecological reservoir in bats.

patterns: How long is the incubation period for COVID-19?
How long does the virus survive on surfaces?
Is it safe to receive a package from any area where COVID-19 has been reported?
response: Most estimates of the incubation period for COVID-19 is two week, most commonly around five days. The likelihood of an infected person contaminating commercial goods is low
Studies suggest that coronaviruses may persist on surfaces for a few hours or up to several days.
This may vary under different conditions.
There is currently no data available on stability of 2019-nCoV on surfaces.
WHO continues to monitor existing evidence around nCoV and will update when such evidence is available.

patterns: How to clean soiled clothing from patients with COVID-19?
What is the best way to clean soiled linen?
What should be used to clean soiled linen?
What is recommended for washing and disinfecting thing?
What are the disinfectants recommended for cleaning?
response: Washing by machine with warm water and laundry detergent is recommended for cleaning and disinfection of linens.
Linen can be soaked in hot water and soap in a large drum, using a stick to stir, avoiding splashing
Soak linen in 0.05% chlorine for approximately 30 minutes.
Rinse with clean water and let linen dry fully in the sunlight.
There are many disinfectants, including commonly used hospital disinfectants, that are active against enveloped viruses.
Environmental cleaning should use disinfectants that are active against enveloped viruses.

patterns: Is there a vaccine, drug or treatment for COVID-19?
response: There is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-2019 yet.
Most patients recover thanks to supportive care.
WHO is coordinating efforts to develop vaccines and medicines to prevent and treat COVID-19.

patterns: Do patients with suspected or confirmed need to be hospitalized if they have mild illness?
What is the best way to treat illness?
what should i do when i was confirmed?
response: For patients who have mild illness, hospitalization may not be required unless there is concern for rapid clinical deterioration.
Ideally, suspected and confirmed 2019-nCoV acure respiratory disease patients should be isolated in single rooms.

patterns: How the new coronavirus spreads?
How does the virus spread?
How does COVID-19 spread?
Am I at risk for COVID-19 from a package or products?
Can mosquitoes or ticks spread the virus that causes COVID-19?
Can someone who has had COVID-19 spread the illness to others?
Can coronavirus be spread through food?
Can I get sick with COVID-19 if it is on food?
response: The virus that causes COVID-19 is mainly transmitted through droplets generated when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or speaks.
This evidence demonstrates viral transmission by droplets and contact with contaminated surfaces of equipment.
The virus that causes COVID-19 spreads from person to person. People are thought to be most contagious when symptomatic (the sickest).
The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person to person, mainly through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

Coronaviruses are generally thought to be spread from person to person through respiratory droplets. Currently, there is no evidence to support the transmission of COVID-19 associated with food, ticks, or other things.
Based on information about this novel coronavirus thus far, it seems unlikely that COVID-19 can be transmitted through food, mosquitoes, or other things but through people.

At this time, CDC has no data to suggest that this new coronavirus or other similar coronaviruses are spread by food, mosquitoes, or other things. The main way that COVID-19 spreads are from person to person.
This coronavirus is thought to be spread most often by respiratory droplets. Currently, there is no evidence to support the transmission of COVID-19 associated with imported goods or other things.

patterns: Should I wear a mask to protect myself?
Should children wear masks?
Does CDC recommend the use of facemask?
response: CDC recommends that everyone 2 years and older wear a cloth face covering that covers their nose and mouth when they are out in the community.

patterns: Wie kann ich meinem Kind helfen, weiter zu lernen, während die Schule ausfällt?
Werden die Kinder während der Schulzeit Zugang zu Mahlzeiten haben?
Wie kann ich mich auf den Fall vorbereiten, dass die Schule, die Kinderbetreuungseinrichtung oder die Universität meines Kindes geschlossen wird?
response: Bleiben Sie in Kontakt mit der Schule Ihres Kindes.
Erkundigen Sie sich bei Ihrer Schule nach den Plänen.
Sprechen Sie mit der Schule oder Einrichtung über ihren Notfallplan.

patterns: Wird das warme Wetter den Ausbruch von COVID-19 aufhalten?
Welche Temperatur tötet das Virus, das COVID-19 verursacht?
response: Es ist noch nicht bekannt, ob Wetter und Temperatur die Verbreitung von COVID-19 beeinflussen.
Im Allgemeinen überleben Coronaviren bei höheren Temperaturen und höherer Luftfeuchtigkeit kürzer als in kühleren oder trockeneren Umgebungen.
Wir haben keine direkten Daten für dieses Virus, und wir haben auch keine direkten Daten für einen temperaturbasierten Grenzwert für die Inaktivierung zu diesem Zeitpunkt.

patterns: Was ist das Coronavirus?
Warum wird die Krankheit COVID-19 genannt?
Was ist COVID-19?
response: Ein neuartiges Coronavirus ist ein neues Coronavirus. Das Virus, das die Coronavirus-Krankheit 2019 auslöst, ist nicht dasselbe wie die Coronaviren, die häufig unter Menschen zirkulieren und leichte Krankheiten wie Erkältungen verursachen.

COVID-19 wird durch ein Coronavirus namens SARS-CoV-2 verursacht. Coronaviren sind eine große Familie von Viren, die bei Menschen und vielen verschiedenen Tierarten, darunter Kamele, Rinder, Katzen und Fledermäuse, verbreitet sind.
Die neue Bezeichnung für diese Krankheit lautet Coronavirus-Krankheit 2019, abgekürzt COVID-19.
In COVID-19 steht 'CO' für 'Corona', 'VI' für 'Virus' und 'D' für 'Krankheit'.

patterns: Was sollte ich tun, wenn es in meiner Gemeinde zu einem Ausbruch kommt?
Sollte ich zur Arbeit gehen, wenn es in meiner Gemeinde einen Ausbruch gibt?
Was kann ich tun, wenn es in meiner Gemeinde zu einem Ausbruch kommt?
Wie geht man mit einem Ausbruch von Covid-19 um?
response: Bleiben Sie während eines Ausbruchs ruhig und setzen Sie Ihren Bereitschaftsplan in die Tat um.

Befolgen Sie den Rat der örtlichen Gesundheitsbehörden. Bleiben Sie zu Hause, wenn Sie können. Arbeitgeber sollten sich darüber im Klaren sein, dass möglicherweise mehr Arbeitnehmer zu Hause bleiben müssen, um sich um kranke Kinder oder andere kranke Familienmitglieder zu kümmern, als dies bei einem Ausbruch der Krankheit in der Gemeinde üblich ist.
Je nach Situation können Sie sich an die örtlichen Behörden wenden, um Ratschläge für den Umgang mit Ausbrüchen zu erhalten.

patterns: Wie kann ich mich auf COVID-19 testen lassen?
Was muss ich tun, wenn ich einen Test für COVID-19 machen möchte?
response: Das Verfahren und die Orte, an denen Tests durchgeführt werden, variieren von Ort zu Ort. Wenden Sie sich an Ihre staatliche, lokale, stammesbezogene oder territoriale Behörde, um weitere Informationen zu erhalten, oder wenden Sie sich an einen medizinischen Anbieter.
Das Covid-19 erhalten Sie in den örtlichen Testzentren oder Sie können die Selbsttestsets kaufen.

patterns: Was sollten Angehörige der Gesundheitsberufe und Gesundheitsämter wie die CDC tun?
Was unternimmt die CDC gegen COVID-19?
response: Für Empfehlungen und Hinweise zu Personen, gegen die ermittelt wird.
Infektionskontrolle, einschließlich Anleitung zur persönlichen Schutzausrüstung.
Häusliche Pflege und Isolierung sowie Untersuchung von Fällen.
Die CDC arbeitet mit anderen Bundespartnern an einer regierungsübergreifenden Reaktion.
Die CDC arbeitet rund um die Uhr, um die Gesundheit der Menschen zu schützen.

patterns: Sollte ich den Kontakt mit Haustieren oder anderen Tieren vermeiden, wenn ich an COVID-19 erkrankt bin?
Kann ich COVID-19 von meinen Haustieren oder anderen Tieren bekommen?
response: Sie sollten den Kontakt mit Haustieren und anderen Tieren einschränken, solange Sie an COVID-19 erkrankt sind.
Es wird empfohlen, dass Personen, die an COVID-19 erkrankt sind, den Kontakt mit Tieren einschränken, bis mehr Informationen über das neue Coronavirus vorliegen.
Wenn Sie an COVID-19 erkrankt sind, sollten Sie den Kontakt mit Ihrem Haustier vermeiden, z. B. durch Streicheln, Kuscheln, Küssen oder Ablecken und gemeinsames Essen.
Derzeit gibt es keine Hinweise darauf, dass das Virus, das COVID-19 verursacht, über die Haut oder das Fell von Haustieren auf Menschen übertragen werden kann.

patterns: Sollte ich mich auf COVID-19 testen lassen?
Warum sollte man einen Test auf Covid-19 machen?
response: Nicht jeder muss sich auf COVID-19 testen lassen.

intents.tag: people with high risk for serioius illness
patterns: Für wen besteht ein erhöhtes Risiko einer schweren Erkrankung durch COVID-19?
Welche Personen sind am ehesten gefährdet, durch COVID-19 ernsthaft zu erkranken?
Wer ist gefährdet, eine schwere Krankheit zu entwickeln?
response: Nach heutigem Kenntnisstand besteht für die folgenden Personen ein hohes Risiko, an COVID-19 schwer zu erkranken: Menschen im Alter von 65 Jahren und älter.
Menschen, die in einem Pflegeheim oder einer Langzeitpflegeeinrichtung leben.
Menschen jeden Alters mit Grunderkrankungen, insbesondere wenn diese nicht gut kontrolliert sind.
Menschen mit chronischen Lungenerkrankungen oder mittelschwerem bis schwerem Asthma.
Menschen, die an schweren Herzerkrankungen leiden.
Menschen, die immungeschwächt sind.
Menschen mit schwerer Fettleibigkeit.
Menschen mit Diabetes.
Menschen mit chronischen Nierenerkrankungen, die sich einer Dialyse unterziehen.
Menschen mit Lebererkrankungen.

patterns: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
What are the symptoms and complications that COVID-19 can cause?
response: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, tiredness, and dry cough.
Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea.
Some people become infected but don’t develop any symptoms and don't feel unwell.
Current symptoms reported for patients with COVID-19 have included mild to severe respiratory illness with fever1, cough, and difficulty breathing.

patterns: What about imported animals or animal products?
Can I travel with dogs or import dogs during the COVID-19 outbreak?
response: Please refer to CDC’s requirements for bringing animals. The current requirements for rabies vaccination apply to animals imported from a high-risk country for rabies.

intents.tag: risk of infection contacting with dead people
patterns: Am I at risk if I go to a funeral or visitation service for someone who died of COVID-19?
Am I at risk if I touch someone who died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
response: There is currently no known risk associated with being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who died of COVID-19.

COVID-19 is a new disease and we are still learning how it spreads. The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to mainly spread from close contact with a person who is currently sick with COVID-19. This type of spread is not a concern after death.

patterns: Is there a model for setting up an isolation ward and types and products and health requirements?
response: A model for setting up an isolation ward is currently under development.

patterns: Can chlorine solutions be used?
response: Chlorine solutions are strongly discouraged as they carry a higher risk of hand irritation and ill health effects from making and diluting chlorine solutions, including eye irritation and respiratory problems.
No, there is a risk of loss of antimicrobial effect if exposed to sunlight or heat.

patterns: Can antiretrovirals be used to treat COVID-19?
Can antiretrovirals be used to prevent COVID-19 infection?
response: While the evidence of benefit of using antiretrovirals to treat coronavirus infections is of very low certainty, serious side effects were rare.

Two studies have reported positive results of the use of LPV as post-exposure prophylaxis for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV. However, the certainty of the evidence is very low due to small sample size, variability in drugs provided, and uncertainty regarding intensity of exposure.

patterns: What studies on treatment and prevention of COVID-19 with antiretrovirals are being planned?
response: Several randomized trials are planned to assess the safety and efficacy of using antiretroviral drugs for treating COVID-19, in combination with other drugs.

patterns: What is physical activity?
Why do we need physical activity?
How much physical activity is recommended?
So how do I stay safe while exercising in COVID-19?
How do I stay active in and around the home?
response: Physical activity includes all forms of activerecreation, sports participation, cycling and walking, as well as activities you do at work and around the home and garden.
Regular physical activity benefits both the body and mind. It can reduce high blood pressure, help manage weight and reduce the riskof heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, and various cancers.
It improves bone and muscle strength and increases balance, flexibility andfitness.
For older people, activities that improve balance help to preventfalls and injuries.

For children, regular physical activity helps supporthealthy growth and development and reduce the risk of disease in later life, and through regular activity, children can develop fundamental movement skills and build social relationships.
Regular physical activity improves mental health and can reduce the risk of depression, cognitive decline and delay the onset of dementia - and improve overall feelings of wellbeing.

patterns: How much physical activity is recommended?
How do I stay safe while exercising in COVID-19?
How do I stay active in and around the home?
response: Infants under the age of 1 year need to be physically active several times a day.
Children under 5 years of age should spend at least 180 minutes a day in physical activities, with 3-4 year-olds being moderately or vigorously active for an hour a day.
Older adults with poor mobility should do physical activity to enhance balance and prevent falls on 3 or more days per week.
Do not exercise if you have a fever, cough and difficulty breathing. Stay home and rest, seek medical attention and call in advance.

patterns: How many malaria-affected countries have reported cases of COVID-19?
response: Malaria-endemic countries in all WHO regions have reported cases of COVID-19.

patterns: Should core malaria vector control interventions be maintained in view of the rapid global spread of COVID-19?
Should core malaria vector control interventions be maintained in view of the rapid global spread of COVID-19?
Should WHO-recommended preventive therapies be maintained in sub-Saharan Africa?
response: WHO strongly encourages countries not to suspend the planning for or implementation of vector control activities, including ITN and IRS campaigns, while ensuring these services are delivered using best practices to protect health workers and communities from COVID-19 infection.
Modifications of planned distribution strategies may be needed to minimize exposure to the coronavirus.

Yes, delivery of intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy, seasonal malaria chemoprevention, and intermittent preventive treatment in infants should be maintained provided that best practices for protecting health workers and other front-line workers from COVID-19 are followed.

patterns: What additional special measures may be needed in the context of COVID-19?
response: In addition to routine approaches to malaria control, there may be a case for special measures in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic such as a temporary return to presumptive malaria treatment.
The use of mass drug administration which have proved useful in some previous emergencies.

patterns: Why is WHO particularly concerned about the spread of COVID-19 in malaria-affected areas?
response: Experience from previous disease outbreaks has shown the disruptive effect on health service delivery and the consequences for diseases such as malaria.

The 2014-2016 Ebola outbreak in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, for example, undermined malaria control efforts and led to a massive increase in malaria-related illness and death in the 3 countries.
In recent weeks, the COVID-19 pandemic has tested the resilience of robust health systems around the world.

patterns: What are the key considerations for countries that are working to eliminate malaria or prevent re-establishment of transmission?
response: Efforts must be sustained to prevent, detect and treat malaria cases while preventing the spread of COVID-19 and ensuring the safety of those who deliver the services.
Countries that are nearing malaria elimination must protect their important gains and avoid malaria resurgences.
Countries that have eliminated malaria must remain vigilant for any imported cases of malaria that may be occurring to prevent reintroduction of the disease.

patterns: What is WHO's position on the use of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, antiretrovirals or corticosteroids in the context of the COVID-19 response?
response: WHO is actively following the ongoing clinical trials that are being conducted in response to COVID-19, including studies looking at the use of chloroquine and its derivative, hydroxychloroquine, for treatment and prevention.
Currently, there is insufficient data to assess the effectiveness of this for treating COVID-19.
WHO has designed a set of procedures to assess the performance, quality and safety of medical technologies during emergency situations.

The current interim guidance from WHO on clinical management of severe acute respiratory infection when COVID-19 infection is suspected advises against the use of corticosteroids unless indicated for another reason.

patterns: If countries use antiretrovirals for COVID-19, are there concerns about treatment shortages for people living with HIV?
response: Any country that allows the use of HIV medicines for the treatment of COVID-19 must ensure that an adequate and sustainable supply is in place.

patterns: Should pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV with COVID-19 and their newborns be managed differently?
Are pregnant women at higher risk from COVID-19?
How can pregnant women protect themselves against COVID-19?
Can COVID-19 be passed from a woman to her unborn or newborn baby?
Can COVID-19 be passed from a woman to her unborn or newborn baby?
Should pregnant women be tested for COVID-19?
response: WHO recommendations are that pregnant women with symptoms of COVID-19 should be prioritized for testing.
No difference is known for pregnant women for now
Research is currently underway to understand the impacts of COVID 19 infection on pregnant women.
Pregnant women should take the same precautions to avoid COVID-19 infection as other people.
It is still unknown if a pregnant woman with COVID-19 can pass the virus to her foetus or baby during pregnancy or delivery.

patterns: Are smokers and tobacco users at higher risk of COVID-19 infection?
response: Smoking products such as water pipes often involve the sharing of mouth pieces and hoses, which could facilitate the transmission of COVID-19 in communal and social settings.
Conditions that increase oxygen needs or reduce the ability of the body to use it properly will put patients at higher risk of serious lung conditions such as pneumonia.

patterns: What care should be available during pregnancy and childbirth?
response: This includes antenatal, newborn, postnatal, intrapartum and mental health care.

patterns: Do pregnant women with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 need to give birth by caesarean section?
response: No. WHO advice is that caesarean sections should only be performed when medically justified.

patterns: Can women with COVID-19 breastfeed?
Can I touch, hold and breastfeed my newborn baby if I have COVID-19?
response: Yes. Women with COVID-19 can breastfeed if they wish to do so.
Yes. Close contact and early, exclusive breastfeeding helps a baby to thrive.
